The Great Analysis🔽The chapter on training rules
The second training rule on loud noises

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāsaddaṁ mahāsaddaṁ karontā antaraghare nisīdanti …pe….
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū uccāsaddam mahāsaddam karontāḥ antaraghare nisīdanti pe
translated: the monks from the group of six were sitting in inhabited areas making loud noises and being boisterous. …

analyzed: appasaddaḥ antaraghare nisīdissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will sit quietly in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.”
One should sit quietly in inhabited areas.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca uccāsaddaṁ mahāsaddaṁ karonto antaraghare nisīdati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.🔽Anāpatti—
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca uccāsaddam mahāsaddam karontaḥ antaraghare nisīdati āpatti dukkaṭassa  anāpatti
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, sits in an inhabited area making loud noises and being boisterous, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
There is no offense if it is unintentional, if he is the first offender,
or if he is insane.🔽The fourth training rule is finished.
